DIV1.HEAD: TO DAVID GARRICK, ESQ
DIV1.P: THE following little whimsical trifle cannot, with propriety, be addressed to any one but to You. It was owing to your persuasion that it ever appeared upon the Stage at all: And it is equally indebted to the same friendly partiality that it still continues to amuse the Town.
I take this public opportunity of thanking you for the trouble you have given yourself about so slight a thing; and with great plea∣sure subscribe myself,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your obliged friend and humble servant, The AUTHOR.

LIST.ITEM: Mr. GRISKIN, a wealthy Citizen, Mr. PARSONS.
Miss GRISKIN, his Niece, Miss POPE.
JEMMY TWINKLE, a City Apprentice, Mr. BRERETON.
Mrs. FILLAGREE, House-keeper to Mr. Griskin, and Governess to Miss, Mrs. BRADSHAW.

YOUNG COUPLES, going to, and returning from Scotland.
Mr. PALMER,
Miss BURTON, &c. &c.

LANDLADY,
CHAMBERLAIN,
HOUSE-MAID,
at an Inn on the North-road,
Mrs. LOVE.
Mr. BOOTH.

Hostlers, Postilions, Servants of the Inn, &c. &c.

DIV1.HEAD: A TRIP to SCOTLAND.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter CUPID, as PROLOGUE, in the Habit of a Postilion.

LG.L: YE belles, ye beaus, of whatsoe'er degree,
Above, below, around; behold in me
A modern Cupid; not like ancient Love
On nimble wings, but post-horses, I move.
Their idol's arms let Heathen bards recount,
This is my bow, I smack it, and I mount.
My spurs are pointed arrows in disguise,
And this broad belt the bandage from my eyes.
Nay ev'n those wings which once out-stripp'd the wind
Hang dangling now like shoulder-knots behind.
For you transform'd I quit the Paphian grove,
Cold Scotland's now the only land for love.
For Scotland ho!—on no fool's errand sent,
I come myself, my own advertisement.
Ye blooming maids, whom half-pay captains press,
Or struck, perhaps, with Robin's rainbow dress,
Who in assemblies sigh, or pine in shades:
Ye youths, who languish for your mother's maids,
Why will ye idly wait for twenty-one?
Behold your vassal! Mount, and let's be gone.
Despise what vulgar mortals prudence call;
Love is the word, and love can equal all.
The eager hostler in the passage stays,
My steeds are ready harness'd to my chaise:
And if this season ends as it began,
Egad, next year I'll drive a caravan.
Does no one want me?—But the cause I see;
You're all asham'd before good company;
Well then, I never blab; my province is
To deal in secrets: but remember this—
In eight-and-forty hours we reach the borders.
—I'll in the green-room wait for farther orders.

DIV1.STAGE: [CUPID waves his whip, and goes out. The Scene shifts.]
A Room in Mr. GRISKIN'S House.
Enter FILLAGREE hastily, followed by Mr. GRISKIN.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: As I hope to live and breathe then, I know nothing at all of the matter. I wish I may be burned if I do. You are eternally suspecting me.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P:
Don't be in a passion, Fillagree, don't be in a passion.—Zoons, 'tis I that ought to be in a passion. Has not my neighbour Flack been telling me here
for this twelvemonth past; Griskin, says he, that niece of yours will be ruined, will be undone.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: What is old Flack to me? let him trouble his head with his own business, and take care of his own daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Ay, there's a girl, Fillagree, there's a jewel of inestimable price! And a fine scholar too, Fil∣lagree; why her aunts tell me that she read through a whole circulating library once, in half a year.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I am out of patience!—Why are my ears to be stunned for ever with Miss Flack's perfections? Who can give a young lady a better education than myself? And have not I exerted all my abilities in accomplishing Miss Griskin?—But I see, after all the pains and trouble I have taken, you want to get rid of me—and so, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I don't, I don't, Fillagree.—But zoons, what does the education you have given her signify, if you contrive to ruin her at last.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I contrive to ruin her?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Why have not you always suffered this young fellow to be hankering about the house? Does not he drink tea forsooth with my niece and you? And are not you continually gadding to Islington with them on a Sunday? Ah Fillagree!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P:
Suppose we do go to Islington on a Sunday: is taking a little fresh air one day in the week such a mighty matter? Are not we stived to death here, in this narrow street, with a cheesemonger on one
side of us, and a tallow-chandler on the other?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Zoons, am I against your taking the air? But why must Jemmy Twinkle be of the party?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Because he is a very genteel creditable young fellow, and the best company in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: There, there now; don't you allow that you admit him?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Did I ever deny it? I like Mr. Jemmy most exceedingly. Lord, he talks so charmingly. He knows every thing that is done at the polite end of the town. He goes to the Bedford Coffee-house, and behind the scenes at the Play-houses, and tells one such comical stories of the wits, and the play∣ers, and the Covent-Garden ladies, and—

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: What is all that stuff to him? Why does not he mind his own business?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Why so he would if you did not prevent it. Stuff indeed! Lord help you. If Miss Griskin was my niece twenty thousand times over, and had twenty thousand times more money than she has, Jemmy should be the man.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: There, there again! and yet you pretend to be angry at my suspecting you.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: So I do, because you suspect me wrongfully.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Wrongfully? Why don't you say—

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P:
No, no I tell you; I don't say any thing.—As
to the match, I approve of it. But you accuse me of being aiding and abetting in their elopement, as you call it. Now that I positively deny. For tho' I love young people should come together as well as any body; yet I always chuse it should be ho∣nourably.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Honourably?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Yes, honourably. Why might not you and I, and the young couple, have gone a little party of pleasure together in a coach to Highgate, or on the water to Greenwich, and have had them married, and bedded honourably?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Don't make me mad. You know I could never consent to it.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: And see what your hard-heartedness has pro∣duced. As the case stands now, were I in your place, I would pursue them to the world's end. Lord, I am frighted to death to think what may happen. Two young giddy people got together, without a prudent friend to advise them to moderate their passions, and put a bridle, as it were, upon their desires.—O, if you had heard the lessons I gave them when we walked to Islington. Indeed, I went with them for that very purpose. Mr. Jemmy, says I —Miss Griskin, says I—

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Poo, Pox! What signifies what you said to them. How is one to find them now? Where can one go after them? ten to one they are gone away to Scotland.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I wish they may with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Wish they may!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Yes, certainly. For if they will do a foolish thing, one should chuse to have it a fashionable one. They tell me that road is full of young couples: And Jemmy always loved to act like a person of distinction. O, he is not such a sneaking devil as you and old Flack are.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: What do you mean, Fillagree? What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I don't know what I mean, not I. You put one in a passion, and then one says any thing.— I ask your pardon.

STAGE.HI: [In a grumbling manner, with a kind of half-curtsy.]

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Well, well, I forgive it.—But what is to be done? I am half mad. Where shall I go?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Go! To every inn in town where they let post-horses. Inquire of every body you meet, man, woman, and child; and, if you hear any thing of them, drive after them immediately. You ought to be at Barnet already; for I dare swear they are gone to Scotland.—What do you stand fretting and teazing yourself for? Go, go, I say.

STAGE.HI: Pushing him to the door.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I will, I will, Fillagree. Mercy upon me, I am in such a fidget!—Whither shall I go first?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P:
Any where, every where.—My poor, dear Miss, she may be ruined and undone by this time; and all from your monstruous behaviour. Get you
gone, can't you. You are as slow in preventing the mischief, as you was cruel in exposing her to it.—Come, come, I will force you out.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN. (turning back and looking at her.)
SP.P: Ah, Fillagree! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE. (looking after him, and mocking him.)
SP.P: Ah, Griskin!—an old curmudgeonly fellow! if it was not for me, there would be no spirit, po∣liteness, or generosity in the family.—Let me see that he is gone tho'. Yes, the door claps; and from this window I can observe which way he goes.—O, down the street, trot, trot, with his hands dangling, and his head noddling. O he is a sweet creature!—He has turned the corner; and now for my young lovers.

STAGE.HI: Opening a closet door.

SP.P: Come out, ye couple of young handsome devils you, come out. Here have I been swearing thro' thick and thin for you.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: O my dear Mrs. Fillagree!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Ay, ay, you have a deal of gratitude at present; but how will it be a twelvemonth hence.—Hey, day, Miss! you look quite mournful. What is the matter with you?

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: I don't know what is the matter with me. I am not well, I believe, Fillagree.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P:
Not well! Odd's my life, is this a time to be ill in? To-morrow, and to-morrow, and to-mor∣row,“” as Mr. Jemmy used to say.—Why you
ought to be half way to Scotland by this time. Come, come, pluck up your spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: My heart misgives me, Fillagree.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: My dear Miss!—

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: It does, indeed, Mr. Twinkle.—My uncle has been very good to me, and I have always be∣haved hitherto like a sober girl, and a very dutiful niece; and I should not care to forfeit that charac∣ter now I am grown a woman. I am sure Miss Flack would not do so.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Racks and tortures!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Bless me, Miss, what is all this! Sober! duti∣ful! good to you! Who can have put such idle notions into your head? You have not told any body of your intentions besides me, have you?— I'll be hang'd if you have not been talking to Miss Flack.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: No, indeed, Fillagree. They are my own re∣flections. They came across me whilst I was shut up in that dark closet with Mr. Twinkle.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: And why Mr. Twinkle, my angel? Why not your tender, your affectionate Jemmy, whose very soul is yours?—Can you forsake me? Can you for∣get you ever said you loved?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE, (aside to Jemmy.)
SP.P: Ay, ay; ply her that way.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P:
I assure you, Mr.—Mr. Jemmy, I love you as much as ever I did; and it goes to the heart of me
to refuse you.—This I can promise you, that I will never marry any other man as long as I live. Besides, I shall be of age, you know, in four or five years time.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Four or five years! Four or five ages. Do you take me for an antediluvian? Any lover since the flood would have died with expectation in half that time.—Unkind and cruel!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Don't accuse me of unkindness, Jemmy. Don't accuse me of that. I cannot bear that.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: She softens.—Why these are arrant vapours, Miss. A journey in the fresh air is absolutely ne∣cessary for you. There is not a physician in Lon∣don but would prescribe it. The sooner you get into the chaise, and the further you go, the bet∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Ay, there again, Fillagree: to leave all one's friends and relations, and run into the wide world. —You know I never was ten miles from London in my life before.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: So much the better. The air will do you the more good now.—I really don't know, (to Jemmy) whether she ought not to go part of the way on horseback.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: No, no, indeed, Fillagree, no: I cannot ride, —What do you look so melancholy for, Jemmy?

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P:
Can you ask me that question? Did not you talk this moment of the wide world, of friends, of re∣lations? Ah! Miss Griskin, it is into these arms
you run, not the wide world. This amorous circle shall protect my fair one. I am every friend, every relation, in one; your lover, guardian, uncle, every thing!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS, (with a sigh.)
SP.P: How charmingly he talks!—What would you advise me to, Fillagree? Shall I venture?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: To be sure; and make as much haste as possible too; for the old man may be back every moment. Here, here, talk to her, whilst I fetch down the little band-box she is to carry in her lap. (Going. Returns.) You are sure you have every thing ready, and where the old fellow cannot possibly find you out?

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Yes, yes; we are all right there—my dear madam! Taking Fillagree by the hand.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Get you gone; it is not my hand you should squeeze so.—What did you let her make reflections in the closet for?

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY, (a little fluttered.)
SP.P: Why, we were afraid of Mr. Griskin.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Psha, Psha! Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: What does she say, Jemmy?

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Say, my adorable? that I am the happiest man in the universe. My heart is again at ease. How could you alarm the poor flutterer?—O let me clasp thee to me!—Hyblaean bees!—Nectar and am∣brosia!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: I believe, verily, you have bewitched me, Jem∣my.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Away, away, you will have toying enough in the chaise.—You must go out at the back-door. I will do every thing in my power to retard the old man's march; and, if I find we are likely to over∣take you, I will hire the postilion to overturn us.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Ten thousand thanks!

SP.SPEAKER: MISS.
SP.P: Good by'e, Fillagree;—heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Nay, nay, no more melancholy. Carry her off, carry her off. Jemmy carries off Miss in his arms.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: What is come to the girl! She was ready enough I am sure this morning. I am afraid the young spark has not so much spirit as I thought he had. I shall be in a fine situation, if she should give him the slip before I have carried my own design into execution.—But mum! the old wretch is come in without my hearing him. He could not meet them, for they went the other way.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I have found them, Fillagree;—I have found them.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I hope not. (Aside.) —Where, dear Sir, where?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: At the very first place I went to.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I am glad of it, with all my heart. And have you brought them back?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: No, no. They went for Scotland before day-break. But I shall be after them directly. There were four or five couple set out at the same time; and, by the description, they are all so like my niece and her sweet-heart, that one of the couples must be they.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Then you don't know that they were they for certain?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I tell you there were four or five couple, and they were all so like, that they must be among them. Why all London cannot afford another couple of the same sort.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE. (Aside.)
SP.P: Five hundred at least.—We are pretty safe, I find.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: But we must not stand prating here. Our chaise will be at the door immediately. I ordered the boy to come as quietly as he could, and up the other end of the street, that the Flack family may know nothing of the matter. Therefore put up a shirt or two for me, and what little things you will for yourself, and—

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: For myself?—Why, do you think that I will go with you?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: To be sure, Fillagree.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: What! I trust myself in a post-chaise with a man alone, running I know not whither?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Dear, dear What, not with your old master?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Old master! Some people may make themselves older than they are for aught that I know, merely to bring about their wicked purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Lud! Lud! I never had any wicked purposes.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I don't know that. I have seen you leer at me sometimes in a manner which I thought very im∣proper.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: How can you talk so?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Why, can any thing be worse than a proposal to me now, which must sully my reputation with the whole neighbourhood. What do you think the Flack-family will say of me? Pray, Sir, have I ever behaved in your house in a manner to encourage it? My unspotted reputation!
"The man who fishes from me my good name," as Jemmy Twinkle says, "Poor me, indeed!"

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: You will absolutely make me distracted.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I am sure you deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: You know you may trust me.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Trust you? — To tell you the truth, I hardly know whether I dare trust myself. You are an old man, to be sure; but I'cod you are a very smug one. And how does one know what the devil may put into one's head.—I will not go, positively.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Now, dear Fillagree.—

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Keep your distance. Don't grow fond, I beg of you. It frights me to death. I am all over in a tremble.—I will go, however, and get your things ready, for I think I hear the post-chaise stop at the door.— But I desire you would not come up stairs after me, for I am resolute in my determination.

STAGE.HI: Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I will follow you tho', for I am sure you love the Girl so much that you must comply. And there shall be no pains wanting on my side to bring it about.—Hark! It is the chaise. I hope old Flack has seen nothing of it. I will just go and speak to the boy.—Poor Fillagree! I do not believe she has her equal for virtue in the world. She is rather a comely woman too, and tho' her temper is a little violent, she has many good qualities.—A smug old man; he, he!— I wish I have not more to fear on my side than she has on her's.—But go she must, at any rate. A smug old man, he, he! Exit.

STAGE.HI: The Scene Changes.
A Dance of Postilions and Chambermaids.

LG.L: Well, Gentlefolks, tho' you refuse my aid,
I've got good customers, and been well paid.
And now, in hopes it may encourage you,
I'll show you what the power of love can do.
Your Grecian bards in their immortal scenes
Have deities descending in machines;
And many a knotty point their Godships clear,
Which you, bold sons of Britain, scarce would bear.
—Hold! scarce would bear?—not in a serious play,
But in a trifling farce perhaps you may;
Where Love the great magician waves his wand,
And then, as Chorus, lends a helping hand.
Hey, pass, begone! swift as the lightning's gleam,
Or lying Mahomet's fictitious dream,
Time, space, be nothing!

STAGE.HI: [On his waving his Whip, the Scenes shift, and the Inn appears.]

LG.L: Since I saw you last
Days have rolled on, and weary miles been pass'd;
Without one seeming interval between,
You're now in Yorkshire, and the scene an inn.
Where couples throng like clustering bees in swarms,
And all my rabble rout are up in arms.
Hark! Do you hear them? What a pleasing brawl!
Bells jingle, chaises rattle, hostlers bawl,
And lovers join in one great caterwawl!
Play with your fancies then, as Shakespear says,
And think all real which our scene displays.
Play with your ears, and swell the noise more loud,
Play with your eyes, and multiply the crowd.
—And lo! to make the strong deception warm,
Our landlady appears! Herself a storm!
A storm I fly from. Runs off.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter LANDLADY, with a Croud of young Couples.

STAGE.HI: Postilions, Hostlers, Servants of the Inn, &c. car∣rying Trunks, Portmanteaus, Band-boxes, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Joseph! Thomas! Betty! Where are ye all?— Show the Lion there.—If you please to step be∣hind the bar, ladies, for a moment.—Light a fire in the Pelican.—O! as private as you please ma'am; a two pair of stairs room, Betty, for this gentle∣man and lady.—Bless me! John Hostler, why don't you look about you? There are two chaises now jammed together in the gateway.—Indeed, madam, you need be under no apprehensions; nobody comes into my house to disturb company. —Lights, there, lights!—I'll wait upon you presently, Sir; be so good to follow the servants, you will find every thing commodious.—Here, James, take this candle.—That fellow is drunk now, but I will give it him in both his ears when he is sober, I can assure him.—Good gentlemen and ladies, I will attend you all as soon as this hustle is a little over.—Show this lady to the lar∣der; ducks, chickens, rabbits, eels, and all kinds of butcher's meat.—It shall be as safe, ma'am, as if it was in your own custody; put it into the bar there.—
Mercy on us, what a hurry do we live in! But now, thank heaven, one may breathe a little.

STAGE.HI: Coming forward.

SP.P:
Well, these Scotch marriages are glorious things for our road. Heaven bless their good hearts who first thought of evading the law. Nothing but post-chaises day and night, night and day; from
London to Scotland, from Scotland to London; up and down, down and up: and then the young couples are such open-hearted, generous souls, that I warrant you some of them spend half their for∣tunes in the journey.—What are become of all my servants? Betty, I say, Betty!

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: Here, madam, here.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: What are you always out of the way for? Prat∣ing with the chamberlain I suppose upon the stairs, or letting some of the gentlefolks' footmen pull you about.

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am, you sent me up stairs with the gentleman and lady.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Well, well, so I did.—Let the sheets be aired for the Antelope;—and do you hear, Betty, ask all the couples who are going down to Scotland, whe∣ther they chuse one bed, or two. As to those who are coming from it, we put them to bed together of course you know, and sometimes, 'egad, against their will. Exit Betty, grinning.
Joseph Chamberlain!

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Pray is that young couple come back again yet, that we had such a fuss about the other day?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P: Not unless they came back in the night, ma'am, when it was Thomas's turn to set up, or called at the other inn.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Poor girl, she was in a terrible taking. But he was a coaxing young rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P: Yes, yes, ma'am; we men know how to ma∣nage ladies. Rubbing his hands.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Aye, fie upon you, fie upon you. My poor husband, I am sure, had none of those wheedling ways with him.—Go, go, there are two or three bells ringing. Exit Chamberlain.

A good neat tight-made young fellow, now I have got him to wear white stockings, and a chitter∣ling. But I shall turn Betty away, I can assure him that, if he follows her in the manner he does, a pert trollop! I wonder the fellow has not more ambition in him.

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: O, ma'am, ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Well, what is the matter now? Bawling enough to split ones ears.

SP.SPEAKER: BETTY.
SP.P: The young couple are come again, ma'am, that you was so fond of.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Lord bless them! Shew them in.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Miss GRISKIN as Mrs. TWINKLE.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: My dear Madam! Running up to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: O Mrs. What-d'ye-call-'em! I am glad to see you again. Lord, I am quite another creature now.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: I am mighty happy to see your ladyship in spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Spirits! Lord ma'am, why I am married, and every body that is married is in spirits you know.— Pray, Mrs.— I cannot think of your name— How old was you when you was married?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: O dear madam, we poor folks don't marry so early as the gentry. I was on the wrong side of thirty, I can assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P:
Bless my soul! Thirty? Why I shan't be se∣venteen these six months. One may have half a do∣zen husbands before one is thirty. If my dear Jemmy was to die to-morrow — What can be be∣come of him? He grows so loitering. Haggling, I suppose, with the postilions. I am sure they
ought to be well paid, for they drove most de∣lightfully. Whisk away, splash and dash, through thick and thin; chatter went the glasses, niddle noddle, bounce forward, bounce backward; O it was charming!—Pray was you married in Scotland, Mrs. Thing'em'me?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: No, dear madam, not I; there was no such good doings in my time.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: For my part I will never be married any where else, if I am married fifty times.—What can my husband be about? My husband, he, he! How I shall laugh at Miss Flack.—Come, Jemmy, come!

STAGE.HI: Taking him by the hand as he enters.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Don't be so teizing.—You should not be so fond before company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Lord, you are grown so crusty.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY. (Curtsying.)
SP.P: Give you joy, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY. (Counting his Money.)
SP.P: Thank you, thank you, good woman.—They have cheated us of a mile or two, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs TWINKLE.
SP.P: Well, and what does that signify; have not we money enough to pay for it?—Pray, Mrs. What's-your-name, can I have a dish of tea?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: I will order it immediately, madam,—So, so!

STAGE.HI: [Looking at them and shaking her head as she goes out.]
[Mrs. Twinkle comes up to Jemmy, leans her arm on his shoulder, pats his cheek, and then speaks.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Wont you put our wedding in the news paper, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Psha! You put every thing out of my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs TWINKLE.
SP.P: Why there is no company here now, is there?

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: When a man is married, madam, and the cares of the world are coming upon him, he has some∣thing else to think of than toying with his wife. We had fooling enough in the chaise, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Fooling do you call it? I am sure I thought it was very pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: When do you think of writing to your uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: I don't care a pin's point for my uncle, not I.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: But we must care about your portion, madam, or we shall make a strange figure in the world.— Now I am thinking.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P:
Aye, but you should not think at all Jemmy, if it makes you so fretful.—I am sure I think of nothing
but you. [Taking him by the hand, and making him drop his money.]

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Don't be so foolish.—See what you have done now!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Well, well; I'll pick it up for you.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY. (Looking in.)
SP.P: The tea is ready, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Very well, Mrs. What-d'ye-call-'em.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Go, go, drink your tea, and let me consider a little with myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE. (Going.)
SP.P: I won't drink a drop till you come. Comes back. Nay I wont stir a step without you. How can you be so cross, Jemmy? are all your vows and pro∣mises come to this? Did not you tell me too that you would write some verses upon our marriage, and put them into the news-paper? I'cod, if you do not, I will shew the world how you did love me once, that I will, and put in my own name too, not Caelia, as you used to call me. I have all your poems in my pocket-book.—There is, "On Cae∣lia's first appearance at Haberdasher's-hall."— "On seeing Caelia walk down Cheapside, while Bow bells were ringing"—And that very pretty one "On Caelia's biting off the finger of her glove at White-Conduit-House"—I will be hanged if there is any thing like that in all Pope's works.

DIV1.STAGE: [During this Speech of Mrs. Twinkle's, Jemmy's Countenance clears up gradually, till at last he smiles and speaks.]

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Why that, that is tolerable, I must confess. I was rather happy there.—But you are a flattering hussey.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Flattering? It ought to be printed in letters of gold. "Sweet lovely maid, were I a glove."—Eh Jemmy!—Come, you shall go and drink tea with me.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Well, well; I don't much care if I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE. (Taking him by the Hand.)
SP.P: I knew you would be a good dear at last. Sweet “”lovely maid, were I a glove—I can say it by heart, I can assure you.—My dear, dear Mr. Twinkle.

STAGE.HI: Hanging upon him as they go out.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: I am heartily glad it has ended so well. I was sadly afraid they would have quarrelled. Men are men I see in all stations; it is her turn to wheedle now. [A noise without.] What is all that bustle about?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P: O ma'am, ma'am; here are the strangest couple come! They cannot be going to Scotland, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: What are they? Who are they?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P:
I cannot guess, ma'am; but the old man is so fu∣rious, and boistrous; he flounced out of the chaise,
and hobbled away to every room he could come at, opened all the doors, disturbed all the company, and has put the whole inn in an uproar.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Where are all my servants? Call the constable; no body shall break open a door in my house. Bless me, what a racket he has made!

STAGE.HI: Several couples run in, very much alarmed.

SP.P: This way, ladies; this way, gentlemen. Here Betty, John, Thomas, put all the company into the great dining-room, and lock the door after them— Pray excuse it—I beg ten thousand pardons.

STAGE.HI: They go out in a bustle.

SP.P: He has not been above stairs, has he?

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P: Not yet, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Nor he shan't neither. Why don't you send for the constable?

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Ay, ay, send for the constable. I will search every room in the house, and every corner in every room.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Indeed but you shall not, Sir. Where is your officer? [Putting herself in his way, and spreading her petticoats.]

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P:
Fie, fie, Mr. Griskin, how can you expose your∣self thus.— Dear good madam, reach me a chair;
I am frighted and fatigued to death.—Don't mind him, Mrs. What-d'ye-call-'em, don't mind him.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: I am sure, madam, I do nothing uncivil to the gentleman; but to have one's house disturbed at this rate—

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: For shame, Mr. Griskin, be quiet.—Did not you promise me in the post-chaise not to be riotous?— I am ready to die—We shall stay here all night, madam. In a languishing tone to the landlady.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: All night? I won't stay an hour after I have searched the house.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE. (rising hastily.)
SP.P: Then by my soul, since you make me swear, you shall go by yourself. Is all your wheedling and nonsense come to this? Have I exposed my cha∣racter, exposed my person, to be used at this rate at last?—Go, be a monster,—and leave me.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN. (looking sheepish)
SP.P: She makes an arrant fool of me.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, the lady advises you all for your own good. You had better be pacified. Shew another room, Betty.—Your ladyship and the gentleman lie in the same bed, I presume?

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: In the same bed, woman? In the same bed?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: You may have two beds in the same room, or chambers adjoining, if your ladyship pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P:
I am ruined, I am undone; my reputation is gone for ever!—See you wretch, how injuriously I
am treated upon your account—O it will break my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Don't cry, Fillagree, don't cry.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Don't come near me.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Nay now, madam, indeed your ladyship is to blame, for the gentleman seems to grow very loving.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: I shall faint, I shall die! Don't use such expres∣sions, woman.—Heigh-ho!—Have you never an honest virtuous neighbour, who could let me have a bed out of the house?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: To be sure such things are to be had, ma'am; but if your ladyship does not chuse to lie near your spouse—

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Spouse?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: I say, ma'am, in such a case we have a long gal∣lery, where you may have six bedchambers between you.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Have not you two galleries!

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P:
We had, ma'am, before the house was burnt down; but when the insurers built it up again, we thought as how that one might be sufficient, and so made the rooms on the second story, ma'am, more larger and more commodious. They are all double beds, and mighty convenient, I can assure you. I have lain in them all round in my poor husband's time; but since that I have confined myself intirely to the little room behind the bar,
where I have a small press-bed, ma'am, that I can easily shut up, ma'am; and then, as your ladyship knows, it makes a very pretty parlour. A great many gentlemen who frequent this house—

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Well, well; I dont't want the history of the bed or the gentlemen; I am not used to such conversa∣tion—But the rooms you were speaking of, are you sure there are six chambers between them?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: At least, madam; your ladyship may see them yourself if you please, and be an eye witness.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Well then that may do.—But I must have one of your maids to sit up with me, for fear of any intrusion.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Poor lady!—Shall I lead you into the next room, ma'am, and bring you a glass of hartshorn and water.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Any where to be away from him.

STAGE.HI: Exit, leaning on the Landlady.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: What surprising virtue! Why she is chaster than Susannah.—Let old Flack say what he will, I must make her reparation.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY. (returning.)
SP.P: Go Sir, comfort your poor lady; she is in a pite∣ous taking.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I am almost afraid to go to her. But I will ven∣ture.—I believe I had as good have a glass of harts∣horn and water too. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P:
Hoity toity! here is more fuss with one old couple than with twenty young ones. But I am
glad the inn is quiet again.—You may let the com∣pany out of the dining room.

SP.SPEAKER: CHAMBERLAIN.
SP.P: O ma'am, the young couple you love so much belong to those old folks who came last. They were just got to the lady as the old fellow came to her, and there is fine work among them.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Ay, ay; that signifies nothing. The deed is done, you know, and I warrant old Hocus must come down with his money-bags.—I'll try if I can over-hear them, for I love such sport dearly.—Let Betty alone, can't you.

DIV1.STAGE: [Pushing out the chamberlain before her; Betty follows, making mouths behind her back.]

LG.L: Ha ha, ha ha, Ha ha ha!
Cupid triumphs o'er all ages,
Beardless youths, and bearded sages
All submit to Cupid's law.
Ha ha, ha ha, Ha ha ha!
Conquest to the Fair belongs,
Be they foolish, be they witty,
Be they frightful, be they pretty,
All ay all have flattering tongues.
All ay all have flattering tongues.

STAGE.HI: He speaks.

LG.L: Well, thus far I have brought, you see,
My couples pretty handsomely;
And every thing has been exprest:
—Then why proceed? You know the rest.
You know in cases such as these,
How nature works by just degrees;
What dreadful storms at first arise
Of clamorous tongues and weeping eyes,
Till all their griefs beyond expressing,
End in a calm, and, Sir, your blessing.
Suppose we then our doating sage
Has spent his impotence of rage;
That pouting Miss had wept her fill;
That Fillagree with female skill
Has touch'd each kind consenting chord,
Has wheedled, threaten'd, and implor'd,
And brought at length her several views,
Just to the crisis she would chuse.
By your consent the rest we'll spare,
Jump to th' event, and catch them there.

STAGE.HI: *He waves his whip.

LG.L: They rise, they speak! and I refrain—
Be courteous, and I'll come again.

STAGE.HI: Nodding to the audience, and exit.

DIV1.STAGE: * On CUPID'S waving his whip, the scene shifts, and discovers Mr. Griskin and Fillagree in earnest conversation on a couch, Miss leaning against one side-scene pouting, and leering at Jemmy, who leans against another scene twirl∣ing his hat, and playing with his fingers. The Landlady, servants of the inn, &c. appear list∣ening at the several doors.]

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE [rising and coming forward.]
SP.P: Well then, upon that condition, and upon that condition only, there's my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN. (grasping her hand eagerly.)
SP.P: 'Tis a hard one, Fillagree.—But I must comply. Come hither, you ungracious couple you; I am forced to forgive you.—Get up, get up, and don't plague me any more about it. You may thank Fillagree for it. I was as hard as adamant till she softened me. Ogling her.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Ten thousand thanks, my dear madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE. (embracing her)
SP.P: My good Fillagree!

STAGE.HI: [Landlady, servants, young couples, &c. run in, in a croud, and Cupid among them.]

SP.SPEAKER: ALL.
SP.P: Give you joy, ladies; give you joy, gentlemen; give you joy.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Hey toss! here is a fine company of you!—and the fiddles too!

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Yes yes, Sir, we have always fiddles ready for such joyful occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I'dod, then, we'll have a dance.

STAGE.HI: He talks apart with the Landlady and Fillagree.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: Dear Jemmy do look yonder; there is Miss Trot, and Miss Sneak, and Miss Giddy—and as I hope to live that little postilion that drove us so well—Come hither, my dear; there's half a crown for you, child. [Chucking Cupid under the chin] — I'cod, Jemmy, if you grow crusty again, I'll run away with that pretty postilion, as sure as you are alive.

SP.SPEAKER: CUPID. (bowing and strutting)
SP.P: I shall be at your Ladyship's service, at a mo∣ment's warning.

SP.SPEAKER: JEMMY.
SP.P: Get away, you young dog you.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Ay, ay, get away!—And now, Fillagree, I have but one care remaining; if I could but get over that cursed difficulty of the Flack family, I should be a happy man indeed.

STAGE.HI: [A Voice from the Croud.]

SP.P: O I can hold no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: What is the matter there?

STAGE.HI: [A young Woman, coming forward.]

SP.P: O Sir, O Mr. Griskin, you know my friends, you know my relations—Behold upon her knees poor Dolly Flack!

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Miss Flack! impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE, Mrs. TWINKLE, &c.
SP.P: Miss Flack!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLACK.
SP.P: How low has love reduced me!

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Rise, rise, Miss Flack—I shall burst out a laughing. [Aside to Fillagree, who lifts up her hands and eyes.] I do know your friends, I do know your relations—But how—what—Why sure your edu∣cation—I cannot hold, Fillagree. Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLACK.
SP.P: Talk not of education, my education has un∣done me. Alas, Sir, from all my reading, I drew but one idea; 'twas that of love. Not formal mercenary love, which comes attended with settle∣ments, and all the odious incumbrances of jointures and pin-money; but that resistless passion, that in∣stantaneous emotion, that fascination of eyes which kindles into rapture even at the first approach— Such I thought this gentleman's affection for me. Can it be wondered at, then, that I should consent to elope with him?

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of young Women.
SP.P: O no, certainly not.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN. (to Fillagree, who checks him)
SP.P: I shall burst.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLACK.
SP.P: The morning was a fine one; a gentle shower had laid the dust, and the air breathed sweetly.— To Barnet, to Hatfield, to Biggleswade, to Bug∣den, nothing so kind as he! At the next stage, I know not why, he grew more cool, then sullen, then ill tempered His sighs for me were changed to execrable oaths. The roads, the postilions, and every inn disgusted him. 'Till at the last, even at this fatal place, he owned, the monster owned, he loved no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of young Women.
SP.P: O fie, fie!

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: How is this? What is all this? Come forward young man, and answer for yourself. Who are you? What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: YOUNG MAN.
SP.P:
My name, Sir, is Sotherton, Tom Sotherton, at your service. My profession is that of a strolling player. The accusation which is laid against me is undoubtedly a true one. And in order to account for my behaviour, with the leave of this good com∣pany,
I will a round unvarnish'd tale deliver
How I did thrive in this fair lady's love,
And she in mine.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of young Men.
SP.P: Ay, ay, hear him! hear him!

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Speak then, young man; but let it be as short as you can, and in plain English.

SP.SPEAKER: SOTHERTON.
SP.P:
In plain English then, Sir, I went to town in hopes of being engaged at one of the theatres, when a
friend of mine pointed out to me the happier pros∣pect of succeeding with this young lady. He knew, pardon the expression, the romantic turn of her disposition: [The young men titter; the girls look down.] He told me likewise that she was cer∣tainly possessed of ten thousand pounds in her own disposal—"'Twas on that hint I spake."

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of young Men.
SP.P: Right, right, Sotherton.

SP.SPEAKER: SOTHERTON.
SP.P: It was last Monday was se'nnight, and it is now Wednesday, that I had the first opportunity of ad∣dressing her. She was turning the corner of a nar∣row street within ten yards of her own house, pas∣sing, as it should seem by the thread-paper in her hand, to a milliner's a few doors below. I gazed, I stopped, and expressed my admiration by a low bow. She blushed and curtsied. I seized her hand, she endeavoured to pull it from me. I pro∣tested my intentions were honourable, and she not only let me keep her hand, but kiss it. We began then to be afraid of observation. We parted; each with a sigh, but not without a promise of meeting again the next day, in the same place, at the same hour. In short, we met every day the whole week through, sometimes for a quarter of an hour, sometimes for half an hour; till at the last our lucky stars gave us an hour compleat; at which interview she kindly consented to elope with me.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: Hey day! Monday a quarter of an hour—Tues∣day—Wednesday—half an hour—a whole hour— Why then about three hours and an half did the business, He, he, he!

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: You were very hasty indeed, Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLACK.
SP.P: Why I was afraid of being found out, Mrs. Fil∣lagree, if I had let him court me any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of young Women.
SP.P: To be sure, to be sure!

SP.SPEAKER: SOTHERTON.
SP.P: The journey proceeded as the lady has already described. At Stilton, the post where she says my coldness began, an express overtook me, sent by the same kind friend who had first proposed the un∣dertaking.—Fatal express to both of us! for it in∣formed me that the ten thousand pounds were so far from being in Miss Flack's own power, that they depended not only on her father, but on a grandmother, and two maiden aunts. What then was to be done? Could I ruin the lady? Could I ruin myself? No, with a truly heroic resolution, I stifled my own passion, and by pretended ill usage endeavoured to put an end to her's.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of young Men.
SP.P: Very honourable, very honourable indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: SOTHERTON.
SP.P: So that you will perceive, Sir, at least the good company will perceive, that whatever effect the late run of sentimental comedies may have had upon their audiences, they have at least made the play∣ers men of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLACK.
SP.P: You are a villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: He talks very finely tho' for all that, Miss Flack. And is a very pretty man too.—I wish you health and happiness, Mr. Sotherton.

STAGE.HI: Dropping a Curtsy, half-aside.

SP.SPEAKER: GRISKIN.
SP.P: I can hardly speak for laughing.—Come, come, Miss Flack, never mind him, you shall return with us, and I will make up the affair with your rela∣tions—Old Flack can't find fault with us now, Fil∣lagree, he, he, he! There is nothing like having one's friends and acquaintance in the same scrape with one's self.—But let us have the dance, for by their looks, half the couples here else will have some complaint or other to make. He, he!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. TWINKLE.
SP.P: You may take out Miss Flack, Jemmy; I shall dance with Mr. Sotherton.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE. (in a half whisper.)
SP.P: Hark you, Miss Flack, have you preserved your virtue?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLACK.
SP.P: O yes, indeed, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.P: Then you may defy the world; and learn from my example, that the woman who preserves her virtue, will always be rewarded at last.

STAGE.HI: [Before the dance, Fillagree comes forward with Cupid in her hand, by way of Epilogue.]

SP.SPEAKER: FILLAGREE.
SP.L: Ladies, you'll witness what this boy has done,
What fools he makes us, and what risques we run,
When this vile gad-fly goads us,
This puppet thing, this miniature of man!
What say you, shall I brain him with my fan?
Or in the very Zenith of his glory,
Here with my glove-string strangle him before you?
—You're tender hearted. Well then, so am I.
Methinks it were a pity Love should die.

LG.L: Love cannot die, whilst so much beauty reigns
In yon fair circle.—
Say, ye nymphs, ye swains,
Was it not right one knotty point to clear,
That Love himself should be in person here?
That boys should match with girls, and girls with boys.
Mere nature can produce such idle toys.
But sure it asks some supernatural aid
When such a lover sighs for such a maid.

STAGE.HI: Pointing to Fillagree and Griskin.

LG.L: Besides, ye fair, from me perhaps you'll hear
What from mere mortals might offend your ear.
Between ourselves, I cannot quite approve
This modern bare-fac'd hurrying into love.
My ancient chiefs, so fam'd for love and war,
Besieg'd whole ages the obdurate fair.
Now, e'er the lover wooes, the lady's won,
And half the sex run post to be undone.
Be wise, be cautious; keep this truth in view,
Few hasty marriages are happy too.
Approach with awe th' indissoluble bands,
Try well your hearts before you yield your hands.
Let each kind parent's voice compleat the plan,
And blush consent even then, behind your fan.

DIV1.STAGE: Country Dance of the Characters, lead by CUPID.
